event.title: Terra Nova (the Antarctic Race to the South Pole) by Ted Tally
event.description: <p>\'Terra Nova\' is the story of that fatal expedition, and of Scott\'s the discovery that the Norwegian explorer Amundsen had beaten him to the Pole.</p>\n
event.full_description: In the winter of 1911-12, five Englishmen and five Norwegians raced each other to the bottom of the Earth. Only the Norwegians returned. Terra Nova is the story of Captain Scott’s expedition to the South Pole. The discovery that Amundsen has preceded him, the bravery and sufferings of his team, the self-sacrifice of Captain Oates and the final tragedy, are recounted in a mixture of fantasy and realism which underlines both the human and the epic qualities of the adventure. Terra Nova premiered at the Yale Rep in 1977 and its 1984 NYC production earned the writer an OBIE Award. The name is taken from the title of Captain Robert Scott’s ill-fated early 20th century, scientific expedition to the South Pole, whose name itself was taken from the whaling ship on which they travelled. Playwright, Ted Tally is perhaps best known for winning the 1992 OSCAR for Best Adapted Screen play of The Silence of the Lambs. ‘Terra Nova’ is the story of that fatal expedition, and of Scott’s the discovery that the Norwegian explorer Amundsen had beaten him to the Pole. It opens and closes with Scott writing the final entries in the journal from which all the details of his last weeks are known. The bravery and suffering of his team, climaxing in the famous self-sacrifice of Captain Oates and the final tragedy are recounted in a mixture of fantasy and realism. This is achieved by the conjured presence of Scott’s wife, Kathleen, and, – in a variety of guises – of Amundsen. The play is drawn from the journals and letters found on the frozen body of Captain Scott. Refusing the use of sled dogs as unsporting, Scott and his team struggle to drag their heavy gear across a frozen wasteland, only to find that Amundsen has preceded them to their goal. The play is also a study of British pride and upper-class resolve, Scott’s aristocratic sense of destiny and command, and his young bride’s ability to understand her husband’s compulsive drive while failing to accept his motivations. But it is in the tragic trip back, as the members of the expedition die one by one, that the play reaches its dramatic conclusion, capturing with chilling intensity the awesome bravery of men who must accept the bitter knowledge that suffering and death will be the only reward for their heroism.

Filmmaker and producer Jake Gorst presents the remastered 1959 classic “American Look.”
event.description: <p>The film emphasizes the abundance of consumer goods and the role of design in offering people freedom of choice.</p>\n
event.full_description: This promotional film highlights the Chevrolet automobile line as a showcase of American industrial design and style. It features modern architecture, interiors, packaging, office equipment, and industrial machines, ending with a behind-the-scenes look at the creation of the 1959 Chevrolet Impala at General Motors’ Technical Center in Warren, Michigan. The film emphasizes the abundance of consumer goods and the role of design in offering people freedom of choice. American Look originally premiered at the 1958 American Society of Industrial Designers conference. This screening is the premiere of a meticulously remastered version, sourcing film elements from the collections of Mainspring Archive and the Library of Congress.

event.title: Soul•Fête: A Celebration of Elevated Black Cuisine and Culture
event.description: <p>Experience the innovation and creativity of elevated Black cuisine. </p>\n
event.full_description: Soul•Fête invites guests to go beyond traditional soul food and experience the innovation and creativity of elevated Black cuisine. The evening will feature a delectable menu crafted by the acclaimed **Dr. Chef Alexandria Wilhoite **, showcasing dishes that celebrate the rich culinary heritage of the Black community while pushing the boundaries of modern cuisine. Complementing the culinary journey, the event will also feature live music by the local favorite band, The Misfits, whose vibrant sounds will provide the perfect backdrop for an unforgettable evening of celebration and connection. From vibrant flavors to soulful rhythms, Soul•Fête promises to be a feast for the senses. “Soul•Fête is more than a culinary event; it’s a celebration of Black excellence, innovation, and culture,” said Fatou Niang, Founder/CEO of S.T.A.R. “We’re excited to bring the community together once again to honor the contributions of Black chefs and artists who continue to shape American culture in extraordinary ways.” The event will take place at the Carriage Barn Art Center in New Canaan CT and tickets are available now on STAR Website. Proceeds from the event will support S.T.A.R.’s ongoing initiatives to promote racial equity and celebrate diversity in our community. Don’t miss this incredible opportunity to celebrate Black history, savor elevated cuisine, and dance the night away with friends and neighbors. (21 and older)

event.full_description: Tuesday, Feb. 25 from Noon-1:30pm Lunch & Learn: An interactive iPhone editing workshop with Jane Beiles , acclaimed photographer for publications including The New York Times, Architectural Digest and House Beautiful. The class is designed for any, and all, levels of photographers seeking to elevate their game. Participants will learn how to edit existing photos with the best practices standard to professional imagery. Jane will teach the key editing components and how to put them to use in order to improve your frames for personal or professional use. Takeaways will include a valuable toolkit to both enhance the photos in existing libraries plus informed knowledge to capture better frames in the future. Once registered, if you like, you will have the opportunity to submit an existing photo of yours which may be chosen as one of the frames to be used as a demonstrative learning tool for the class. Jane’s classes are known to be both content-rich and joyful, with valuable educational kernels and more than a few laughs in the mix! The class will be taught on an iphone 16 but nearly all of the elements will be translatable to earlier models as well as to other manufacturers’ devices*.  A brief touch on the new features on the 16 model will be helpful to new users or give owners of older versions information to decide if the investment in a new phone is worthwhile.

Terra Nova (the Antarctic Race to the South Pole) by Ted Tally
event.description: <p>\'Terra Nova\' is the story of that fatal expedition, and of Scott\'s the discovery that the Norwegian explorer Amundsen had beaten him to the Pole.</p>\n
event.full_description: In the winter of 1911-12, five Englishmen and five Norwegians raced each other to the bottom of the Earth. Only the Norwegians returned. Terra Nova is the story of Captain Scott’s expedition to the South Pole. The discovery that Amundsen has preceded him, the bravery and sufferings of his team, the self-sacrifice of Captain Oates and the final tragedy, are recounted in a mixture of fantasy and realism which underlines both the human and the epic qualities of the adventure. Terra Nova premiered at the Yale Rep in 1977 and its 1984 NYC production earned the writer an OBIE Award. The name is taken from the title of Captain Robert Scott’s ill-fated early 20th century, scientific expedition to the South Pole, whose name itself was taken from the whaling ship on which they travelled. Playwright, Ted Tally is perhaps best known for winning the 1992 OSCAR for Best Adapted Screen play of The Silence of the Lambs. ‘Terra Nova’ is the story of that fatal expedition, and of Scott’s the discovery that the Norwegian explorer Amundsen had beaten him to the Pole. It opens and closes with Scott writing the final entries in the journal from which all the details of his last weeks are known. The bravery and suffering of his team, climaxing in the famous self-sacrifice of Captain Oates and the final tragedy are recounted in a mixture of fantasy and realism. This is achieved by the conjured presence of Scott’s wife, Kathleen, and, – in a variety of guises – of Amundsen. The play is drawn from the journals and letters found on the frozen body of Captain Scott. Refusing the use of sled dogs as unsporting, Scott and his team struggle to drag their heavy gear across a frozen wasteland, only to find that Amundsen has preceded them to their goal. The play is also a study of British pride and upper-class resolve, Scott’s aristocratic sense of destiny and command, and his young bride’s ability to understand her husband’s compulsive drive while failing to accept his motivations. But it is in the tragic trip back, as the members of the expedition die one by one, that the play reaches its dramatic conclusion, capturing with chilling intensity the awesome bravery of men who must accept the bitter knowledge that suffering and death will be the only reward for their heroism.

event.full_description: Learn storytelling from the best in this introductory workshop with The Moth. Since its launch in New York City in 1997, The Moth has presented thousands of stories told live and without notes, renowned for the great range of human experience they showcase. In one 3-hour session, participants will learn The Moth’s unique storytelling principles; hear a sample story; brainstorm, reflect, and begin developing a personal story; and connect with others in the room. Spots for this special learning experience are limited and preference will be given to New Canaan Library cardholders.

event.title: Filmmaker and Producer Jake Gorst Presents the Remastered 1959 Classic “American Look”
event.description: <p>This promotional film highlights the Chevrolet automobile line as a showcase of American industrial design and style. It features modern architecture, interiors, packaging, office equipment, and industrial machines, ending with a behind-the-scenes look at the creation of the 1959 Chevrolet Impala at General Motors’ Technical Center in Warren, Michigan. The film emphasizes the abundance of […]</p>\n
event.full_description: This promotional film highlights the Chevrolet automobile line as a showcase of American industrial design and style. It features modern architecture, interiors, packaging, office equipment, and industrial machines, ending with a behind-the-scenes look at the creation of the 1959 Chevrolet Impala at General Motors’ Technical Center in Warren, Michigan. The film emphasizes the abundance of consumer goods and the role of design in offering people freedom of choice. American Look originally premiered at the 1958 American Society of Industrial Designers conference. This screening is the premiere of a meticulously remastered version, sourcing film elements from the collections of Mainspring Archive and the Library of Congress.

event.title: Soul•Fête: A Celebration of Elevated Black Cuisine and Culture
event.description: <p>Stand Together Against Racism (S.T.A.R.) is thrilled to announce the return of Soul•Fête: A Culinary Immersion, an exciting event to honor Black Excellence Month through the artistry of food and music. Back for its second edition, this year’s celebration will take place on February 26th from 6:00 PM to 9:30 PM, offering attendees an opportunity […]</p>\n
event.full_description: Stand Together Against Racism (S.T.A.R.) is thrilled to announce the return of Soul•Fête: A Culinary Immersion, an exciting event to honor Black Excellence Month through the artistry of food and music. Back for its second edition, this year’s celebration will take place on February 26th from 6:00 PM to 9:30 PM, offering attendees an opportunity to further explore the profound influence of Black cuisine on American food culture. Soul•Fête invites guests to go beyond traditional soul food and experience the innovation and creativity of elevated Black cuisine. The evening will feature a delectable menu crafted by the acclaimed **Dr. Chef Alexandria Wilhoite **, showcasing dishes that celebrate the rich culinary heritage of the Black community while pushing the boundaries of modern cuisine. Complementing the culinary journey, the event will also feature live music by the local favorite band, The Misfits, whose vibrant sounds will provide the perfect backdrop for an unforgettable evening of celebration and connection. From vibrant flavors to soulful rhythms, Soul•Fête promises to be a feast for the senses. “Soul•Fête is more than a culinary event; it’s a celebration of Black excellence, innovation, and culture,” said Fatou Niang, Founder/CEO of S.T.A.R. “We’re excited to bring the community together once again to honor the contributions of Black chefs and artists who continue to shape American culture in extraordinary ways.” The event will take place at the Carriage Barn Art Center in New Canaan CT and tickets are available now on STAR Website linked here. Proceeds from the event will support S.T.A.R.’s ongoing initiatives to promote racial equity and celebrate diversity in our community. Don’t miss this incredible opportunity to celebrate Black history, savor elevated cuisine, and dance the night away with friends and neighbors.

event.title: American and International Contemporary Organ Music Concert
event.description: <p>Carson Cooman, Organist and Composer in Residence at the Memorial Church of Harvard University, will present a special program of American and international contemporary organ music at St. Michael’s Lutheran Church in New Canaan, Connecticut, on February 21 at 7 pm.  Carson Cooman, Organist and Composer in Residence at Harvard University Chapel, will present a […]</p>\n
event.full_description: Carson Cooman, Organist and Composer in Residence at the Memorial Church of Harvard University, will present a special program of American and international contemporary organ music at St. Michael’s Lutheran Church in New Canaan, Connecticut, on February 21 at 7 pm. Carson Cooman, Organist and Composer in Residence at Harvard University Chapel, will present a special program of bold, boundary-pushing contemporary organ music on Friday, February 21, 2025 at 7pm  at the historic building of St. Michael’s Lutheran Church, 5 Oenoke Ridge, New Canaan, Connecticut 06840.  Doors open at 6:45pm. Free reception to follow.  Suggested donation $20. Music selections include works by six American and four international composers. Among the American composers are Gwyneth Walker, a prominent American composer and New Canaan resident; Alla Borzova, an award-winning composer and St. Michael’s Director of Music; as well as Karen Beaumont, Nancy Galbraith, Iteke Prins (Netherlans-Canada-USA) and Alexander Dmitriev. International composers include Yûitirô Katô (Japan), Carlotta Ferrari (Italy), and two composers from Sweden: Villemo Daneling and Thomas Åberg. Carson Cooman is an American composer and organist. Since 2006 Cooman has held the position of Organist and Composer in Residence at the Memorial Church, Harvard University. As an organ recitalist, Cooman specializes in the performance of contemporary music. Over 300 new compositions by more than 100 international composers have been written for him. Cooman has made many recordings as organist, including more than 15 complete CD releases of music by contemporary international composers along with several multi-composer albums. Over 300 new compositions by more than 100 international composers have been written for him, and his organ performances can be heard on a number of CD releases and more than 7,000 recordings available online, representing the work of more than 700 composers.  Cooman is a prolific composer. His music appears on over forty recordings, including more than twenty-five complete CDs on various labels. For more information, visit carsoncooman.com

event.title: Men’s Club sets classical musical performance for Friday; Invites public
event.description: <p>The New Canaan Men’s Club will have a notable change from its regular programming at its meeting February 21 when it hosts Jonathan Yates, musical director and conductor of the Norwalk Symphony, and Marina Kitaychik, a violinist with the symphony and music educator, for a performance and remarks about the orchestra, now in its 80th […]</p>\n
event.full_description: The New Canaan Men’s Club will have a notable change from its regular programming at its meeting February 21 when it hosts Jonathan Yates, musical director and conductor of the Norwalk Symphony, and Marina Kitaychik, a violinist with the symphony and music educator, for a performance and remarks about the orchestra, now in its 80th year. Because of Friday’s unique program, the club is welcoming spouses and outside guests to enjoy the performance in St. Mark’s Episcopal Church, 111 Oenoke Ridge, either in person, or online. The performance in the church is scheduled for 10:40 a.m., but it’s requested that guests arrive by 10:30 a.m.  The club will meet at its usual 10 a.m. time for its regular business in Morrill Hall, before adjourning to the church sanctuary for the musical performance and discussion. Yates, an accomplished pianist who has performed with internationally recognized musicians, such as violinist Midori, cellist David Finckel and pianist Gilbert Kalish, has led the symphony since its 2011-2012 season. He received his graduate degree in conducting from the Juilliard School and was the holder of the Bruno Walter Memorial Scholarship. He serves as music director emeritus of the chamber ensemble, Camerata Notturna in New York City. At the Symphony’s next performance, March 23, at 7:30 p.m. in Norwalk City Hall, the Music For All Ages concert includes George Gershwin’s “An American in Paris,” and Aaron Copland’s “Lincoln Portrait,” which will be narrated by Today Show Co-Host Craig Melvin. The Norwalk Symphony’s mission is to “share the beauty and power of orchestral music for audiences of all ages through live performances and music education.” Yates is also musical director and conductor of the Norwalk Youth Symphony, now in its 69th year, which performed in Italy last summer. Kitaychik has studied at the Moscow Conservatory and earned both her bachelor and master of music degrees from Mannes College of Music at The New School in New York. She received chamber music coaching from members of the Shostakovich Quartet, Borodin Quartet, and Orion String Quartet. In addition to attending the performance at the church, the Men’s Club is also making it available to the public online, by clicking the link, Norwalk Symphony at the New Canaan Men’s Club after 10:30am on February 21. The Men’s Club has openings for new members, men 55-years and above. For information about joining, email ncmens@ncmens.club.

event.description: <p>The former executive producer of the acclaimed series, “Live from Lincoln Center,” Andrew Wilk, will give members of the New Canaan Men’s Club a sense of what it takes to produce concerts, theater, ballet and other live productions for PBS when he’s interviewed during the club’s meeting Friday (February 14). The interview is titled: “Creating […]</p>\n
event.full_description: The former executive producer of the acclaimed series, “Live from Lincoln Center,” Andrew Wilk, will give members of the New Canaan Men’s Club a sense of what it takes to produce concerts, theater, ballet and other live productions for PBS when he’s interviewed during the club’s meeting Friday (February 14). The interview is titled: “Creating Music, Theatre, Dance and More for Broadcast.” In his career, Wilk has produced and directed more than 1,000 hours of prime-time television and has won five Emmy Awards, bringing New York Philharmonic concerts, American Ballet Theater performances, productions by the Lincoln Center Theater and ensemble performances by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center to home viewers. A few years ago, he produced Stars on Stage from Westport Country Playhouse featuring performances by Broadway stars Shoshana Bean and the late Gavin Creel, among other Broadway actors, which is available to stream through PBS. Wilk will be interviewed during the meeting by John Brandt, former president of the YMCA’s Men of Westport and Weston. The New Canaan Men’s Club meets at 10 a.m. in Morrill Hall at St. Mark’s Episcopal Church, 111 Oenoke Ridge. Wilk’s interview is scheduled to begin around 10:40 a.m. after the business portion of the meeting concludes. Before executive producing Live from Lincoln Center, Wilk was chief creative officer of Sony Music Entertainment and worked for several television networks, including HBO and Disney. He is also an accomplished stage director, writer and symphony conductor. He has a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree from New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts. event.title: Terra Nova (the Antarctic Race to the South Pole) by Ted Tally
event.description: <p>In the winter of 1911-12, five Englishmen and five Norwegians raced each other to the bottom of the Earth. Only […]</p>\n
event.full_description: In the winter of 1911-12, five Englishmen and five Norwegians raced each other to the bottom of the Earth. Only the Norwegians returned. Terra Nova is the story of Captain Scott’s expedition to the South Pole. The discovery that Amundsen has preceded him, the bravery and sufferings of his team, the self-sacrifice of Captain Oates and the final tragedy, are recounted in a mixture of fantasy and realism which underlines both the human and the epic qualities of the adventure. Terra Nova premiered at the Yale Rep in 1977 and its 1984 NYC production earned the writer an OBIE Award. The name is taken from the title of Captain Robert Scott’s ill-fated early 20th century, scientific expedition to the South Pole, whose name itself was taken from the whaling ship on which they travelled. Playwright, Ted Tally is perhaps best known for winning the 1992 OSCAR for Best Adapted Screen play of The Silence of the Lambs. ‘Terra Nova’ is the story of that fatal expedition, and of Scott’s the discovery that the Norwegian explorer Amundsen had beaten him to the Pole. It opens and closes with Scott writing the final entries in the journal from which all the details of his last weeks are known. The bravery and suffering of his team, climaxing in the famous self-sacrifice of Captain Oates and the final tragedy are recounted in a mixture of fantasy and realism. This is achieved by the conjured presence of Scott’s wife, Kathleen, and, – in a variety of guises – of Amundsen. The play is drawn from the journals and letters found on the frozen body of Captain Scott. Refusing the use of sled dogs as unsporting, Scott and his team struggle to drag their heavy gear across a frozen wasteland, only to find that Amundsen has preceded them to their goal. The play is also a study of British pride and upper-class resolve, Scott’s aristocratic sense of destiny and command, and his young bride’s ability to understand her husband’s compulsive drive while failing to accept his motivations. But it is in the tragic trip back, as the members of the expedition die one by one, that the play reaches its dramatic conclusion, capturing with chilling intensity the awesome bravery of men who must accept the bitter knowledge that suffering and death will be the only reward for their heroism.

event.description: <p>This promotional film highlights the Chevrolet automobile line as a showcase of American industrial design and style. It features modern […]</p>\n
event.full_description: This promotional film highlights the Chevrolet automobile line as a showcase of American industrial design and style. It features modern architecture, interiors, packaging, office equipment, and industrial machines, ending with a behind-the-scenes look at the creation of the 1959 Chevrolet Impala at General Motors’ Technical Center in Warren, Michigan. The film emphasizes the abundance of consumer goods and the role of design in offering people freedom of choice. American Look originally premiered at the 1958 American Society of Industrial Designers conference. This screening is the premiere of a meticulously remastered version, sourcing film elements from the collections of Mainspring Archive and the Library of Congress.

Students learn about human service needs in the surrounding community by volunteering at local nonprofit organizations including Person to Person, Darien Nature Center, At Home In Darien, Waveny Lifecare Network, Open Doors Shelter, and Fairgate Farm.​ There are 7 meetings per semester […]</p>\n
event.full_description: Youth Give Back (YGB) YGB is a program for 7th-8th grade Darien students. Students learn about human service needs in the surrounding community by volunteering at local nonprofit organizations including Person to Person, Darien Nature Center, At Home In Darien, Waveny Lifecare Network, Open Doors Shelter, and Fairgate Farm.​ There are 7 meetings per semester that run for an hour and a half where students volunteer and help with a variety of tasks. ​ Spring Semester Meeting Schedule January 22nd 3:00-4:30pm February 5th 3:00-4:30pm February 26th 3:00-4:30pm March 12th 3:00-4:30pm March 26th 3:00-4:30pm April 9th 3:00-4:30pm April 23rd 3:00-4:30pm ​ *Meeting Locations TBD*: Meetings will be held at local nonprofits where students will be volunteering ​ . Youth Give Back $200 registration fee funds the operation of the youth program: Personnel Refreshments/ snacks Supplies Any remaining funds are contributed to The Community Fund of Darien’s grant giving pool to be invested in helping our community. Registration is now open for The Community Fund of Darien’s Spring Semester of Youth Give Back (YGB), a volunteer youth program for 7th and 8th grade students in Darien. Through YGB, students volunteer with local nonprofit organizations such as Fairgate Farm, Person to Person, Open Doors Shelter, At Home in Darien, and Darien Nature Center. Student volunteers gain hands-on experience addressing critical human service needs in the community while making a meaningful impact. “This program introduces Darien students to the power of volunteerism and opens their eyes to the challenges faced by individuals in our community,” says Sarah McCarty, Thriving Youth Program Director. “One YGB student shared, ‘I learned that acts of kindness can change lives and impact many.’” Last semester, 18 Darien students participated in six local volunteer opportunities. A standout experience for many was time spent at Waveny LifeCare Network in New Canaan, where students connected with residents through engaging activities. Waveny’s Executive Director of Community Engagement, Stella Clarke, shared, “Our residents enjoyed YGB’s visit so much, and many staff members commented on the happy smiles, laughter, and conversation. It was especially nice that having all the extra pairs of hands we were able to bring many of our 50 residents out into the garden to spend time enjoying the sunshine and leaves. The students really engaged well and were kind and friendly with good questions after the activity.” Applications are due January 6, 2024, and can be submitted via the student Google form available on The Community Fund of Darien’s website: communityfunddarien.org/ youthgiveback . This day is the Hindu celebration of Shiva, recognized as a time for spiritual awakening. Restaurateur Nwang Sherpa, a […]</p>\n
event.full_description: On Wednesday, February 26, Himalaya SoNo is preparing to open its culturally rich restaurant, bar, music venue, and retail shop at 99 Washington St. in South Norwalk (with easy parking in the Haviland or Webster lots). This day is the Hindu celebration of Shiva, recognized as a time for spiritual awakening. Restaurateur Nwang Sherpa, a proud immigrant from Nepal, is expanding the Himalaya brand, which has earned a stellar reputation and numerous awards, including Zagat’s Best and Restaurant Guru achievements in its Westchester County locations. Himalaya SoNo embraces the flavors of Nepali-Tibetan fusion cuisine, prepared with fresh, organic Himalayan herbs and spices. Menu highlights include handmade momos (dumplings), a variety of korma (almond and cashew sauce) and curry dishes from throughout the region, tandoori meats and shrimp, the always popular chicken tikka masala, spicy vindaloo, noodle and rice dishes, and a wide variety of vegetarian-friendly specialties such as chana saag (chickpeas in spinach gravy) and dal (lentils) makhini. LEARN MORE

event.full_description: Blossom Hill will hold its annual Valentine’s event, For the Love of a Child, on January 13, 2025 from 12 – 2 pm at the New Canaan Playhouse. All proceeds will support its mission – education for peace – to transform the lives of displaced and at-risk children and youth globally. Start your Valentine’s week with purpose at our cherished annual fundraiser. Drop in with your galentines for an afternoon of connection and giving, featuring: Tea Bar Flower Bar Chocolate Bar Charm Bar Sparkling wine Bar Lite healthy lunch Everyone goes home with a prize What: Blossom Hill’s For the Love of a Child Where: New Canaan Playhouse, 93 Elm Street, New Canaan, CT When: Thursday, January 13, 2025, 12 – 2 pm Tickets:: https://blossomhill-foundation.org/galentine/ —– Blossom Hill is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization based in New Canaan, CT. Founded in 2009, it has been on the forefront of the refugee crisis, working tirelessly to create positive change and uplift communities. Its mission is to implement innovative programs that empower children affected by conflict in the Middle East. To date, Blossom Hill has reached over 130,000 children and youth in 25 countries, as well as right here in CT, with multiple initiatives through a Fellowship Program for Social Entrepreneurs. This model provides a multi-layered impact on both our fellows’ growth and development and positive change in displaced communities.

event.title: Shadow Dance Story Time with Woof Woof the Shadow Pup
event.description: <p>Free Family Program presented at the Carriage Barn in partnership with New Canaan CARES and the New Canaan YMCA Woof Woof the Shadow Pup illuminates the importance of understanding and acknowledging the emotional life of young children. This inspiring story is an invitation for families to experience shadow play at home and in the magical […]</p>\n
event.full_description: Free Family Program presented at the Carriage Barn in partnership with New Canaan CARES and the New Canaan YMCA Woof Woof the Shadow Pup illuminates the importance of understanding and acknowledging the emotional life of young children. This inspiring story is an invitation for families to experience shadow play at home and in the magical world of shadow theater: wondrous worlds where adventure and possibility are never-ending. Leap into the spotlight and explore the art of shadow dance with professional dancers from the children’s theatre production of Woof Woof the Shadow Pup. Children will experience projection art and an interactive story time, participate in immersive shadow dance, and dig into hands-on prop-making. Woof Woof is a bedtime activity created by Nancy Close PhD, Yale Child Psychologist to help children express their thoughts and feelings more easily to an imaginary character. This is a unique Parent-Child experience program for families to help build the skills and relationship where the children feel comfortable and confidence to express their feelings! Are you ready to meet a special friend? Let’s say it together…one, two, three…Woof Woof! Shadow Dance Story Times: 11am, 2pm, 4pm Learn more atwoofwoofshadow.comand follow us on social media@woofwoofshadow Please Register / Space is Limited

event.title: Winter Bird Scavenger Hunt
‘Terra Nova’ by Ted Tally
event.description: <p>In the winter of 1911-12, five Englishmen and five Norwegians raced each other to the bottom of the Earth. Only the Norwegians returned. Terra Nova is the true story of Captain Scott\'s expedition to the South Pole. The discovery that Amundsen has preceded him, the bravery and sufferings of his team, the self-sacrifice of Captain […]</p>\n
event.full_description: In the winter of 1911-12, five Englishmen and five Norwegians raced each other to the bottom of the Earth. Only the Norwegians returned. Terra Nova is the true story of Captain Scott’s expedition to the South Pole. The discovery that Amundsen has preceded him, the bravery and sufferings of his team, the self-sacrifice of Captain Oates and the final tragedy, are recounted in a mixture of fantasy and realism which underlines both the human and the epic qualities of the adventure. Terra Nova premiered at the Yale Rep in 1977 and its 1984 NYC production earned the writer an OBIE Award. The name is taken from the title of Captain Robert Scott’s ill-fated early 20th century, scientific expedition to the South Pole, whose name itself was taken from the whaling ship on which they travelled. Playwright, Ted Tally is perhaps best known for winning the 1992 OSCAR for Best Adapted Screen play of The Silence of the Lambs. ‘Terra Nova’ is the story of that fatal expedition, and of Scott’s the discovery that the Norwegian explorer Amundsen had beaten him to the Pole. It opens and closes with Scott writing the final entries in the journal from which all the details of his last weeks are known. The bravery and suffering of his team, climaxing in the famous self-sacrifice of Captain Oates and the final tragedy are recounted in a mixture of fantasy and realism. This is achieved by the conjured presence of Scott’s wife, Kathleen, and, – in a variety of guises – of Amundsen. The play is drawn from the journals and letters found on the frozen body of Captain Scott. Refusing the use of sled dogs as unsporting, Scott and his team struggle to drag their heavy gear across a frozen wasteland, only to find that Amundsen has preceded them to their goal. The play is also a study of British pride and upper-class resolve, Scott’s aristocratic sense of destiny and command, and his young bride’s ability to understand her husband’s compulsive drive while failing to accept his motivations. But it is in the tragic trip back, as the members of the expedition die one by one, that the play reaches its dramatic conclusion, capturing with chilling intensity the awesome bravery of men who must accept the bitter knowledge that suffering and death will be the only reward for their heroism.

event.full_description: Wednesday, February 12 · 5:30 – 7:30pm EST Location HAYVN 320 Boston Post Road Suite 180 Darien, CT 06820 Show map Refund Policy No Refunds About this event About HAYVN’s Sustainability and Social Impact Group: If you are interested in learning about Sustainability and exploring topics/trends to make a difference please join us. event.title: Noted Astronomer Links Religion and Science at Men’s Club

venue.name: Morrill Hall at St. Mark’s Church

event.description: <p>In remarks combining science and theology, Brother Guy Consolmagno, an astronomer at the renowned Vatican Observatory and the author of numerous books on astronomy and science, will speak to the New Canaan Men’s Club Friday (February 7) when it meets at 10 a.m. in St. Mark’s Episcopal Church 111Oenoke Ridge. In a talk titled “When […]</p>\n
event.full_description: In remarks combining science and theology, Brother Guy Consolmagno, an astronomer at the renowned Vatican Observatory and the author of numerous books on astronomy and science, will speak to the New Canaan Men’s Club Friday (February 7) when it meets at 10 a.m. in St. Mark’s Episcopal Church 111Oenoke Ridge. In a talk titled “When Science Goes Wrong: The Desire and Search for the Truth,” Br. Consolmagno’s comments will focus on the history of science ideas once considered reasonable before being proven wrong. The Men’s Club meeting is scheduled for 10 a.m. with Br. Consolmagno’s remarks set for 10:40 a.m. He holds degrees from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a Ph.D. from the University of Arizona’s Lunar and Planetary Laboratory. He currently is the president of the Vatican Observatory Foundation  and is the recipient of the Carl Sagan Medal of Excellence for Public Communication in Planetary Science. He is the author or co-author of several books, among them “Turn Left at Orion,” “God’s Mechanics, How Scientists and Engineers Make Sense of Religion,” and “Would You Baptize and Extraterrestial,” which draws upon questions sent to the Vatican. In his presentation, “When Science Goes Wrong,” Br. Consolmagno will explore the unpredictable nature of scientific discovery, the role of failure in advancing knowledge, and how unexpected results can lead to groundbreaking insights. Drawing from his extensive experience in planetary studies, his work with the Vatican Observatory, and his lifelong passion for exploring the cosmos, he will offer his perspective on the dynamic and sometimes messy nature of scientific progress. The Men’s Club has openings for men 55-years old and above. For information, email ncmens@ncmens.club.

event.title: Candlelit Soundbath at the Carriage Barn
event.description: <p>The ultimate in self care! Step into a realm of tranquility and profound relaxation at this candlelit sound bath experience with Diane & Catherine of Grounded Meditation. After a brief grounding meditation, amidst the glowing landscape at the Carriage Barn, you’ll be enveloped in a symphony of harmonious vibrations, produced by an assortment of crystal […]</p>\n
event.full_description: The ultimate in self care! Step into a realm of tranquility and profound relaxation at this candlelit sound bath experience with Diane & Catherine of Grounded Meditation. After a brief grounding meditation, amidst the glowing landscape at the Carriage Barn, you’ll be enveloped in a symphony of harmonious vibrations, produced by an assortment of crystal and Himalayan singing bowls, chimes, gongs, drums and more. The gentle hum of the instruments creates a sensory experience that transcends the boundaries of the physical world. Allow the sounds to penetrate deep into your being, dissolving tension, and promoting inner calm and balance. You’ll find yourself drifting effortlessly into a state of deep relaxation, where time seems to stand still and the worries of the day melt away. Let the music guide you as you explore the depths of your consciousness, finding solace and renewal in the stillness within. As the sound bath draws to a close, we’ll wrap up with a body scan and some breath work to leave you  feeling refreshed, rejuvenated, and deeply connected to yourself and the world around you. Emerge from this transformative experience with a sense of peace and serenity as you step back into the outside world, ready to face whatever lies ahead with clarity and grace. Sound Baths have been shown to reduce stress and anxiety; improve sleep; help with depression; lower blood pressure  and bring on an overall sense of calm and inner peace. Please bring a  mat and any other props you would like for comfort- i.e. blanket, eye  covering, pillow, bolster, etc. $40 / person

event.title: Surviving Loss in Tragedies like the LA Wildfries
event.description: <p>A webinar featuring Dr. Ken Druck, an international authority on healing after loss as well as courageous living</p>\n
event.full_description: Voices Center for Resilience presents “Surving Loss in Tragedies like the LA Wildfires, a webinar featuring Dr. Ken Druck, an international authority on healing after loss as well as courageous living. During this presentation, participants will learn to give themselves the permission, support, compassionate self-care and patience necessary to process their losses, honor their loved ones, cultivate a resilient spirit, and summon the courage to go on living. We will discuss life losses where a loved one has died, and living losses where there have been heartbreaking, life-altering, traumatic losses of treasured homes, property, and memories.

event.title: Encaustic Exploration Painting at the Carriage Barn
event.description: <p>This 2-hour workshop with Carolyn Childs introduces this versatile to art medium and teaches various techniques using a hot iron and wax.</p>\n
event.full_description: Come discover and create using the encaustic art medium!  This 2-hour workshop with Carolyn Childs introduces this versatile to art medium and teaches various techniques using a hot iron and wax.  Participants of all artistic skill levels will have the opportunity to create paintings on multiple surfaces. Bring your curiosity to explore art and enjoy a restorative, creative experience with others. Encaustic is a method of painting with wax.  The pure beeswax is mixed with resin and pigments.  Each layer of wax is melted and fused with heat to the substrate.  You will learn how to use this hot wax painting technique to create sublime and beautiful works of art.

event.title: Seasonal Stories with Architectural Photographer James Florio
event.description: <p>Encounter Florio’s creative process during this mid-residency presentation in the Grace Farms Library.</p>\n
event.full_description: Architectural photographer James Florio is Grace Farms ’ Artist-in-Residence, visiting throughout the seasons to build a body of work composed on large format film. Encounter Florio’s creative process during this mid-residency presentation in the Grace Farms Library, which will temporarily transform to display his work, along with curated elements representing his Montana studio. Florio will share stories about immersing himself into the rhythms of nature to document the changing seasons at Grace Farms , in a conversation with Grace Farms Chief Strategy Officer and Founding Creative Director, Chelsea Thatcher . Complimentary tea will be provided. Large format film removes barriers between the viewer and image to capture the world as it is: simple yet complex, imperfect but beautiful. During his residency, Florio explores how the River building—with glass walls that remove barriers between people and nature—transforms with the landscape across the seasons.

event.title: Army Pilot Recalls Flying Vietnam Missions at Men’s Club

venue.name: Morrill Hall at St. Mark’s Church

event.description: <p>The New Canaan Men’s Club will hear about the real-life experiences of U.S. Army pilot, Francis Doherty, who flew covert reconnaissance missions in Vietnam, when it meets Friday at 10 a.m. in Morrill Hall at St. Mark’s Episcopal Church, 111 Oenoke Ridge. Doherty is the author of “Only the Light Moves: Flying Covert Reconnaissance Missions […]</p>\n
event.full_description: The New Canaan Men’s Club will hear about the real-life experiences of U.S. Army pilot, Francis Doherty, who flew covert reconnaissance missions in Vietnam, when it meets Friday at 10 a.m. in Morrill Hall at St. Mark’s Episcopal Church, 111 Oenoke Ridge. 	Doherty is the author of “Only the Light Moves: Flying Covert Reconnaissance Missions in the Vietnam War,” a book recounting the missions he flew and the emotional struggles he and his comrades faced upon returning to the U.S. His remarks will begin at about 10:40 a.m., following the business portion of the meeting. On his missions, Doherty searched out Vietcong troop movements and called out targets for waiting F-4 Phantom jets. Going beyond his year of Vietnam duty as a military pilot, he went onto a career as a commercial airline pilot for 32 years. Doherty is a New Canaan resident and a 1967 graduate of the University of San Francisco. The Men’s Club has openings for new members, New Canaan men over 55-years of age. For information about joining, email ncmens@ncmens.club

event.title: Dancing in the Dark: A History of Dance in the Movies with Brian Rose
event.description: The movies and dancing are a partnership born in heaven. From its very beginnings, the new medium of motion pictures turned toward dance as one of best ways to showcase its unique ability to make movement come alive. Through the decades, it’s been dancing on the big screen that has provided some of the most ecstatic moments in film history—whether it’s Fred Astaire gliding on the ceiling in , the Nicholas Brothers leaping down a staircase in , Moira Shearer pirouetting through the dreamscape of , or John Travolta burning up the dance floor in . Employing more than 75 video clips, this talk will survey 130 years of thrilling movie dance performances and discuss how the cinema helped change the nature of dance. was a Professor of Communication and Media Studies for 38 years at Fordham University's College at Lincoln Center until his recent retirement. He has written several books on television history and cultural programming. He has conducted more than one hundred Q & As with leading directors, actors, and writers for the Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences, The Screen Actors Guild, The British Academy of Film & Television Arts, and The Directors Guild of America.

event.title: Gentle Yoga with Monica Keady
event.description: Gentle Yoga is for anyone who wants to experience a mindful yoga flow that invites you to slow down and move at a steady pace while lingering in poses that feel comfortable and are pain free.  The flow is steady as we attune to the breath, body & mind.  Gentle Yoga relaxes the nervous system and can improve sleep and digestion.  A regular practice will increase strength, balance and flexibility. Participants may bring their own yoga mat and/or a large towel. Monica Keady is a registered yoga teacher and meditation guide certified in the Kripalu tradition - the yoga of compassion.  As a life-long practitioner of yoga, Monica appreciates the serenity and resilience that yoga and meditation provide. Her mission is to share yoga so that others may experience the gifts of a regular practice.  Monica leads mindful movement including Slow & Gentle Yoga, Yin Yoga, Restorative Yoga, and Meditation.

event.title: Film Documentary: "Beyond Zero"
event.description: Darien Library, along with , , , and , will present " ," a documentary about $1 billion, global carpet company, , as it begins to recognize the environmental harm it causes, and the journey that has transformed it into one of the most sustainable companies on Earth. The film begins by following CEO, Ray Anderson, who decides to embark on a mission to eliminate all toxic and negative environmental impacts the company produces by 2020.  In order to do this, he must take a huge risk, abandon the status quo, and overcome deep skepticism.  The end result is the start of a new industrial revolution. "Beyond Zero" has now obtained a series of accolades including The Audience Choice Award at the Denver Film Festival as well as Best Documentary and Best Story at the Boston Film Festival. But, the biggest ripple effects can be seen in the private sector and academia: Major North American companies like KKR, UPS, PWC, and Meta and their peers in Europe, Asia, and Australia have used screenings of the film to show their global teams a better way to think about sustainability. Further, business faculty at Harvard, Yale, and many more around the world have obtained special permission to incorporate the film into their curriculums. Nathan Harvey 2022 Ray Anderson, CEO of Interface This movie is 1 hour and 10 minutes long.

event.title: Business Book Group: The Goal
event.description: Join Darien Library's Business Book Group to discuss by Eliyhu M. Goldratt. Library staff members will lead the discussion. Unlike other book groups, it is not required to read the book before the meeting. The group will informally discuss the book and then spend a few minutes afterward to network with each other. Books will be provided once registration is completed. You will be notified by email when your book is ready for pick-up. Alex Rogo is a harried plant manager who has been given 90 days to save his failing factory. If he doesn't improve the plant's performance, corporate headquarters will close it down and hundreds of workers will lose their jobs. It takes a chance meeting with Jonah, a former professor, to help him break out of his conventional thinking and figure out what needs to be done. As Alex identifies the plant's problems and works with his team to find solutions, the reader gains an understanding of the fundamental concepts behind the Theory of Constraints.

event.title: Storytelling with The Moth
event.description: Learn storytelling from the best in this introductory workshop with The Moth. Since its launch in New York City in 1997, The Moth has presented thousands of stories told live and without notes, renowned for the great range of human experience they showcase. In one 3-hour session, participants will learn The Moth’s unique storytelling principles; hear a sample story; brainstorm, reflect, and begin developing a personal story; and connect with others in the room. Spots for this special learning experience are limited and preference will be given to New Canaan Library cardholders. is downloaded more than 100 million times a year and Peabody Award-winning airs weekly on over 575 public radio stations nationwide. The Moth also runs a variety of different programs to promote the art and craft of storytelling and to honor and celebrate the diversity and commonality of human experience. Their Mainstage tours have featured such well-known names as Elizabeth Gilbert, Hasan Minhaj, Malcolm Gladwell, Darryl “DMC” McDaniels, Molly Ringwald, Krista Tippett, Damon Young, Mike Birbiglia, and Rosanne Cash, as well as an astronaut, a pickpocket, a hotdog eating champion, and hundreds more.

event.title: Joke’s On You: An Afternoon of Humor with Authors Dan Gutman and Alan Katz!
event.description: Get ready for an afternoon filled with laughter and fun as authors Dan Gutman and Alan Katz join us for a hilarious Joke-Off at the library! The authors will talk about their books and writing process, followed by a Joke-Off, Q&A and book signing. Dan Gutman is the beloved author of the series, , and many other stories that make kids laugh out loud while they read. His unique blend of humor and adventure has earned him a spot as one of the top writers for young readers. Alan Katz is the author of the series and , a book packed with silly jokes that kids adore. His funny and imaginative stories encourage laughter while fostering a love for reading and creativity. Don't miss out on this opportunity to meet two of the funniest authors around and enjoy a side-splitting afternoon! After the Joke-Off stay around to ask questions and get your book signed! Elm Street Books will be on-site selling books. has written 50+ highly acclaimed books for young readers. A frequent presenter at regional and national conferences/festivals, he’s received numerous state awards for his titles, notably and Alan is the co-author (with the ’s Dylan Dreyer) of an October 2021 Bestseller. His other recent titles include three Lieographies (Babe Ruth, Amelia Earhart and Thomas Edison), and the first five books in the series. Alan is also a six-time Emmy-nominated writer for TV series including , several Nickelodeon and PBS Kids series, animated shows and , and network specials including the Grammy Awards, the Tony Awards and . was born in a log cabin in Illinois and used to write by candlelight with a piece of chalk on a shovel.  Oh, wait.  That was Abraham Lincoln. Actually, Dan has written 190 books for beginning readers (Rappy the Raptor), young readers (My Weird School), and advanced readers (The Genius Files, Houdini and Me).  Dan lives in New York City.  You can visit his web site ( ) and follow him on Facebook, X, and Instagram.

event.description: Darien Library presents: Monday Night at the Movies! This week we are showing “The Brutalist." Nominated for 10 Oscars, including Best Motion Picture of the Year, Best Achievement in Directing, Best Performance by an Actor in a Leading Role – Adrien Brody, Best Performance by an Actress in a Supporting Role – Felicity Jones. “Escaping post-war Europe, visionary architect László Toth arrives in America to rebuild his life, his work, and his marriage to his wife Erzsébet after being forced apart during wartime by shifting borders and regimes. On his own in a strange new country, László settles in Pennsylvania, where the wealthy and prominent industrialist Harrison Lee Van Buren recognizes his talent for building. But power and legacy come at a heavy cost.”– A24 Brady Corbet 2024 Adrien Brody as László Tóth, Felicity Jones as Erzsébet Tóth, László's wife, Guy Pearce as Harrison Lee Van Buren, Joe Alwyn as Harry Lee Van Buren, Raffey Cassidy as Zsófia, Ariane Labed as adult Zsófia, Stacy Martin as Maggie Van Buren, and Alessandro Nivola as Attila. This movie is 3 hours and 34 minutes and is rated R (for strong sexual content, graphic nudity, rape, drug use and some language).

Henson), Dorothy Vaughan (Octavia Spencer), and Mary Jackson (Janelle Monae), who worked at NASA during the Space Race. event.title: Madness with Best-Selling Author Antonia Hylton
event.description: Widely listed as one of the best books of 2024, tells the 93-year-old history of Crownsville Hospital, one of the last segregated asylums with surviving records and a campus that still stands in Anne Arundel County, Maryland. Award-winning journalist Antonia Hylton traces the legacy of slavery to the treatment of Black people’s bodies and minds in our current mental healthcare system. It is a captivating and heartbreaking meditation on how America decides who is sick or criminal, and who is worthy of our care or irredeemable. Hylton will be in conversation with former ABC News Correspondent and Anchor Heather Cabot. On a cold day in March of 1911, officials marched twelve Black men into the heart of a forest in Maryland. Under the supervision of a doctor, the men were forced to clear the land, pour cement, lay bricks, and harvest tobacco. They became the first twelve patients of the state’s Hospital for the Negro Insane, later called Crownsville Hospital. As Crownsville Hospital grew from an antebellum-style work camp to a tiny city sitting on 1,500 acres, the institution became a microcosm of America’s evolving battles over slavery, racial integration, and civil rights. This program is co-sponsored by LiveGirl and New Canaan Library. Antonia Hylton is a Peabody and Emmy-award winning journalist at NBC News reporting on politics and civil rights, and the co-host of the hit podcasts Southlake and Grapevine. She graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University, where she received prizes for her investigative research on race, mass incarceration and the history of psychiatry. She lives in Brooklyn. Photo credit: Mark Clennon

event.description: Darien Library and welcome Jolene Mullen to discuss French Canadian genealogy. Jolene is a professional genealogist and genealogical speaker specializing in lineage research and New England records. She is a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution and has served as national chair of the Lineage Research Committee, national vice chair of the French Task Force, the Cold Cases Committee and the Chapter Development and Revitalization Committee, twice as a CT DAR state officer, and is the state chair of both the State Application Team and the Chapter Development and Revitalization Committee. is the author of , now a standard reference book documenting civil and patriotic service for American patriots. Her next book, , is in the works. Jolene lives in New Milford and enjoys sewing and quilting in her free time, particularly for the Quilts of Valor Foundation.

Classes & Workshops, 
                      Making & Crafting,

event.description: Welcome to STEAM Lab!  This time is for students ages 10-16 to use the MakerLab, try new equipment and deepen skills. Teen volunteers will be on hand to help assist.  There's lots to explore and you can decide how you want to spend your time. Robotics Station:  Free build with the LEGO Mindstorms EV3 kits or tinker with an Arduino. Textile Station:  We will have one sewing machine set up and supplies for hand sewing.  Try a simple starter project or work on your own project after you've learned the basics.  There's also lot of yarn to knit, crochet or weave. CAD Design:  Use Tinkercad to design for 3D printing or the laser cutter.  During STEAM Lab, only designs that you have created will be 3D printed.  Prints may take longer than class time to complete and can be picked up later. Laser cutter material will be limited to cardboard and scarps of wood. Cricut Cutting Machine: We'll have a featured project to try on the Cricut or you can use the Cricut software or Inkscape to create your own designs. event.title: Alzheimer's Support Group with the Waveny LifeCare Network
event.description: Family members, caregivers, and friends are invited to meet for informative and supportive group sessions to help navigate changes related to memory loss and cognitive decline. This event will be facilitated by Chris DiElsi, a Licensed Master Social Worker (LMSW) and an Alzheimer's Navigator at Waveny LifeCare Network. Attendees can find guidance, offer support, and ask questions in a safe environment. Each meeting you can expect to: -              Discuss and provide coping techniques & strategies -              Share stories and experiences of your own journey -              Share feelings, needs, and concerns -              Learn about community resources The registration list for this event will be shared with Waveny LifeCare.
